| Ghurye                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | - - Methodological pluralism- in empirical exercises or data collection, he was not dogmatic; encouraging disciplined eclecticism<br>        - Eg Field survey- "Sex habits of the middle class people in Bombay" and "Mahadev Kolis"<br>    - Theoretical pluralism. (Inductive + Deductive)<br>    - Stuck to detailed description rather than grand theories (detailed ethnography)<br>    - combined historical, anthropological and sociological perspective<br><br>religion<br><br>- Religion is at the centre of the total cultural heritage of man.<br>- It moulds and directs the behaviour of man in society - similar to Durkheim<br>- six books to bring out the role of religion in society. These are: Indian Sadhus (1953), Gods and Men(1962), Religious Consciousness (1965), Indian Accumulation (1977), Vedic India (1979), and The Legacy of Ramayana (1979).<br>- Sadhus are the social link between spiritual people and common man<br>- Indian Sadhus<br>    - Sociography of the various sects and religious centres established by the great Vedantic philosopher Sankaracharya and other notable religious figures.<br>    - Highlights the **paradoxical nature of renunuciation** in India.<br>    - A sadhu or sannyasin is supposed to be detached from all castes, norms and social conventions, etc. yet strikingly enough, since the time of Sankaracharya, the Hindu society **has more or less been guided by the sadhus**.<br>    - Most of them belonged to monastic orders, which have distinctive traditions.<br>    - The monastic organization in India was a product of Hindusim and Buddhism. The rise of Buddhism and Jainism marked the decline of individual ascetics like Viswamitra.<br>    - Indian sadhus have acted as the **arbiters of religious disputes, patronized learning of scriptures** and the sacred lore and even defended religion against external attacks.<br>- Religious consciousness (book): analyzed three oldest human civilizations (Mesopotamia, Egypt and India  primitive socs) and their religious practices lije worship, afterlife, mythology<br>- Ghurye: basically a one-way flow, in which the Brahminical ideas and institutions infiltrated among the non-Brahmins.<br><br>Muslims<br><br>- View based on 7 centuries of conflicts with muslims<br>- Regarded them as separate groups with little possibility of give and take<br>- Hindu and muslim monuments were diverse value systems (Hindu temples were indigenous in inspiration) whereas Muslims were Arabic or persian<br>- They were more decorative whereas Rajput monuments retained commitment to Hindu ideals<br><br>Culture, civilisation and historical role of cities<br><br>- Rejected the idea that villages are self sufficient  instead they are the centre of social life<br>- Idea of rurbanization (rural + urbanisation) securing the advantages of urban life simultaneously with natures greenery.<br>- During colonial times, the growth of metropolitan centres grew<br>- The towns and cities - **major manufacturing centres**.<br>- Used rural areas for producing raw materials and turned into a market for selling industrial products.<br>- metropolitan economy emerged to dominate the village economy<br>- growth of rural and urban areas is interconnected<br>- Positive view of industrialization  called them cradles of innovation (against Louis Wirths view)<br><br>Culture<br><br>- Attempt to understand roots of culture in his later books like  Family and kin in IndoEuropean culture  idea family had origins in ancient India<br>- Two Brahmanical institutions  Gotra and Charana  spread of these inst from exogamy<br>- Vedic India<br>- 3 elemets  nationalist (tribs), diffusionist (caste), Indilogical (old text)<br>- Acculturations was the vertical integration in Indo European culture in general, Brahmaniacl hindusim in particular<br><br>Criticism of Ghurye \| Indology<br><br>- Caste : Brahminical P.O. V. and Hindu culture only  TK Oomen<br>- Tribe : Integration \| Assimilation is a value loaded concept.<br>- Armed chair theorism<br>- SC\|ST\|OBC\| Muslims as a threat is not acceptable as they widely participated in INM.<br>- Indology does not take into account present contemporary changes highlighted by Field Studies. (eg. Dominant caste, sanskritisation)<br>- contradictory explanation (eg. Colonial VS Nationalist Indologists)<br>- Religious texts presented a value, While reality was different. (Fact vs Value  eg that all Indians stay in joint families)  text cant always show context<br>- Implication of caste on culture?<br>- Favoured caste - Didnt look at dehumanizing effect of caste<br>- said culture holds india together  but was disrupted after muslims came<br>- Dange: Brahmins were respected not due to their knowledge but due to economic perspective | Structural functionalism                                                                                                                                                                                                         | - The Indological approach of Analysing Indian society paved way for structural functionalism under influence of radcliffe and Prichett<br>- Society consists of diff parts which are inter related and operates to maintain cohesion in the system<br>- Functionality tried to find a functional significance of all social institutions like Brahmins, caste, family, religion , caste<br>- Any structural functional study gives emphasis to field work (Positivism)  similar to Durkheim arunta<br>- Institution or object have functions for maintenance of Structure<br>- Inspired by A.R. Radcliffe-Brown<br>- changes as a slow, cumulative process of adjustment, When any change is experienced by any part of society, other parts gradually **re-align** themselves to the change in one part<br>- **Pitchard: anthropolical field**<br>- more on field work to understand context and **field view perspective, while text only tells about norms**<br>- .N. Srinivas, S.C. Dube, McKim Marriott<br>- Basic premise<br>    - Wanted to understand social inst, cultures and traditions in societal structure in a holistic manner at a micro level  Coorgs of Mysore  studies customs, believes<br>    - Want to understand functional role of social phenomena  eg Karves family<br>    - Brought much needed dynamism and heterogeneity<br>- Instrumental in understanding India<br>    - Caste class nexus: as studied by Thomere where Malik, Mazdoor, Kisan = high, middle lower castes<br>    - Class relations: K Gough  capitalism led to consolidation<br>- However<br>    - Ignored conflict and dysfunctional role as a result of dialectics and inherent contradictions<br>    - Status quoist<br>    - Upper caste bias -> lack of empiricism<br>    - Failed to recognize the social | Idea of Indian village                                                                                                                                                                                                           | Pre independence<br><br>- Orientalists:<br>    - Henry Maine: Considered villages as self sufficient units, which were closed, not related to external trade  **Little republics**<br>    - Metcalfe: **little republics  monolithic, unchanging, atomistic**  aim  Vested pol and eco interests<br>        - Autonomous pol councils  usually rule of elderly<br>        - Economic autonomy  self sufficiency<br>        - World view was ltd to everyday life of village<br>        - Coop due to jajmani and inter-dependence of caste<br>        - Communal ownership of land<br>    - **Endorsed by Munro**<br>    - **WH Summer:** Ethnocentric understanding that despite poverty, backwardness, orthodoxy, Indians wont modernize  hence white burden<br>    - **MC Marriot > Culturology** - looked at culture evolution temporally and spatially<br>        - **_Village India: Studies in little economy_**<br>        - Inspired by redfield<br>        - Universalization and parochialization<br>- Nationalists:<br>    - Gandhi  Reproduced colonial idea  represented village as authentic India; Swaraj incomplete without autonomy in pol and economy of villages + need common places for collective gathering and worship<br>    - Nehru  cillage is a problem as dev hasnt reached it  Modernization of village -> it is a storehouse of India and need to modernize without compromising dance, music and cultural ethos of villages  middle path (Discovery of india)<br>    - Ambedkar  dull view  area of ignorance, discrimination, communalism, exploitation, narrow-mindedness, marked by untouchability  plant which grow into hindu tree of purity and pollution<br><br>Ethnographic studies  1950s  post independence to counter book view<br><br>**_1950-1960:_** Village Studies start with Anthropologist, statisticians, economists<br><br>- - - Majorly used st functionalism to have Important contributions<br>        - observe and understand polity, economy, religion, caste<br>        - planning commission  Data collection for policy making<br>        - understand social change introduced by policy<br>        - pattern of living to develop generalization<br>    - MNS <br>        - **_India villages_**<br>        - Questioned book view on village<br>        - Broke the myth of self sufficiency  dependence on other villages for trade and exogamy (shows village not self sufficient)<br>        - Weekly markets such as moving markets were observed too to fulfil economic needs of villages (AM Shah and SC Dube also)<br>        - Jati councils  whose jurisdiction outside villagec<br>        - Dominant caste and social change by Sanskritization  not completely rigid or closed;<br>        - dual hierarchy  impact of land reform and decentralization of power  not independent as impacted by national policies<br>        - saw vertical and horizontal solidarity<br>    - **SC Dubey >**<br>        - Used structural functionalist perspective In his study to analyze diff social institutions and practices in Indian villages<br>        - Wanted to understand village life as representative and diverse as India  Sharmipet chosen<br>        - Indian village<br>        - Features of Sharmipet study<br>            - Inter-dependence of caste group through reciprocal obligation - Criticized the orientalist view of self sufficiency and isolation.<br>            - Instead part of a community which span across boundaries of village; not completely autonomous  redfield inspired ; but was disintegrating due to migration and upward mobility<br>            - Village council - They have own authority<br>            - Village orgs for pol, eco, social services<br>            - Eco based on caste  occupational mobility on caste<br>            - Village see outsider as cohesive group; have factions only within<br>            - Religion  hindu muslim interact increasing horizontal solidarity + had rituals + communal festival<br>        - How to do field work<br>            - Listed elements to be recorded by field workers<br>                - Size and pop of village<br>                - Ethnic/ caste composition<br>                - Pattern of land ownership<br>                - Structure of authority and social composition of authority<br>                - Factors for rule must be noted  ritual and secular<br>                - Degree of isolation from urban area<br>                - Local traditions<br>                - Collective beliefs and world view<br>        - Imp contributions<br>            - Dominant individual, family, faction , multi caste power alliance<br>            - Community dev program  changes after implementation and issues + what are functions role of traditions<br>    - AM Shah (Myth of self suffieicncy of village communities): Challenged self-sufficiency  said not necessary they have all resources. Instead they provide services to other villages<br>    - MSA Rao  moblity in occupation leading to new dominant castes eg Yadavs in his stufy of yadavpur<br><br>**_1960  1970_**  agrarian studies  used Marxist framework for critical research to<br><br>- Didnt study religion etc, but how land is distributed and organized<br>- understand exploitation of peasants/ sharecropper by landowner or landlord<br>- ASS: arrangement of groups, individuals with respect to land ownership and means of prodution<br>- Andre Beteille: Studies IN AGRARIAN SOCIAL STRUCTURE<br>    - Sripuram, Tajore - > Entire undifferentiated to differentiated  CASTE CLASs power<br>    - In Bengal study <br>        - Wanted to understand how local people categorize themselves  class not universal as social construction<br>        - Bhumsami, kheti karne wale, malik, pattedar, batayidar, krishak mazdoor  cannot place individual neatly to them - person can be both owner and tenant<br>        - Dev of sharpy focused class interest  close to impossible<br>        - Land and service and control  more qualitative definition of class<br>        - Diff types of landlords  big landlords, enterprising owners (meticulous in their calculaton), absent landlords, Self cultivating owners<br>        - Diff controllers  only control (manager), control and owner, tenant controller, tenant owner controller<br>        - Diff users  hired labor, bonded labor, contractual, exchange labor<br>- Daniel Thorner  3 criteria to classify wrt land<br>    - Type of Income  rent, own cultivation, wage<br>    - Nature of rights  proprietary rights, tenancy/ sharecropping rights, no rights<br>    - Extent of work done  do not work, partially or complete work with fam labour<br>    - Malik (no work, rent, proprietary) , kisan (ow cultivation, sharecropping right, partially) , mazdur<br>    - Internal differentiation within agrarian classes<br>        - Malik  big landlord (absentee landlord), rich landowner (not absentee but some interest in land mgt)<br>        - Kisan  small landowner (support own fam), substantial tenants (no land and work on someone else land)<br>        - Mazdoor  poor tenant (small holding), sharecropper, landless labourer (no holding)<br>- DN Dhanangre  5 classes in agrarian social structure  peasant movements in india<br>    - landlords (Thorner big landlord),<br>    - rich peasants  rich landowner (rich landowner), rich tenant (Small landowner)<br>    - middle peasant  medium size landholding<br>    - poor peasant - lower<br>    - landless labourer - no<br>        - dhanagre   ASS is so complex that no general schema possible<br>            - family demography is changing<br>            - cost of prod is increasing<br>            - focus is only on rice wheat rather than diversification<br>            - ground water is being depleted<br>            - hence need to focus on growing problems and not only ACS<br>- Utsa Patnaik and Ashok Rudra  Marxist  exploiting and exploited class -> they would re-invest and consolidate position<br>- AR Desai  Peasant struggles in india  land owner and peasant<br><br>**_1990  Present  LPG era  understand market and economy_**<br><br>- Analyzed impact of globalization and withdrawal of welfare state ; intro of pvt players of agri and mfg<br>- Globalization impact<br>    - Growing influence of neo-liberal eco policy  erosion of dev state<br>    - Subsidy, regulated market diluted  farmer exposed to global comp<br>    - Contract farming  cos provides seeds, inputs inl working cap to farmers. In return, farmer assured of pre-determined fixed prices<br>        - Biggest beneficiary were big landowners (who became enterprenurial farmers) and Gentlemen farmers<br>        - Increasing inequality within classes<br>        - R&R  bullock capitalists; tractor capitalists<br>        - Pauperization as loss of jobs of existing farmers<br>    - Monoculture and cash crops (from foodcrops) which had greater dd in global market  coffee, cotton, oilseeds  profit over needs<br>    - Challenge to small farmers  extensive competition<br>    - Destruction of ecology  Vandana Shiva  seeds, pesticides, sanlinzation - soil deption  farmers without security<br>    - Shift to Hydro and aeroponics - becoming prosperous + modern edu through modern labs and plants  inequality increase as less labor, more cap intensive  MN Panini (floriculture in Karnataka study)<br>- vina mazumdar  gender based exploitation intensified after economic growth and women become homemakers<br>- migration - | Definitional problem                                                                                                                                                                                                             | - India has 700+ tribes and constitute 8.6% of Indian pop as per 2011 census; 15% area<br>- Tribes are heterogenous groups with homogenous identity under const 6th schedule<br>- Features  77% anemic, 59% literacy, 63 life expectancy, 45% poverty + 60% dropout<br>- India tribes diff from world as not homogenous<br>- Orientalists and Indologists  not much difference  only of mop and settlement style<br>- MoTA: Ministry of Tribal Affairs, Definition: CP SBI<br>    - 1) Primitive traits<br>    - 2) Distinctive culture<br>    - 3) Geography Isolation<br>    - 4) Shyness from general Population<br>    - 5) Backwardness<br>- Herbert risley and girgson based on residence and culture<br>- JH Hutton  tribes and caste in india - caste and tribe are diff concepts<br>    - Tribes have occupational homegneity whereas castes have occupation heterogeneity<br>    - Live in forest vs plains<br>    - Practice animism and naturalism vs organized structure<br>    - Egalitarian vs hierarchical<br>    - SC Roy  hindusism is a common factor that established unity<br>- Majumdar: there has been a crisscross of tribes except in East<br>- FG Bailey: caste and tribe in continuum (tribe caste and nation)<br>    - Caste and tribe are ideal types<br>        - Caste is oranic and hierarchical  has many units who are interdependent on each other<br>        - Tribes instead are segmentary and independent<br>    - In reality  they sit in between<br>        - Some interdependence in tribes<br>    - Odisha study<br>        - Eg  khonds in odisha  divided into clans and segmentary which are equal  so tribe<br>        - Oriya  organic and hierarchical<br>        - Amongst khonds, panos are present in kondhs but they pick up ddead animals  so some hierarchy<br>    - Moreover, if we take oriyas as a whole with diff villages  brahmins of diff villages are equal to each other  hence equalitarian and segmentory<br>    - Some caste features in tribes and some in caste<br>    - However criticized as no purity pollution in tribes which is imp to caste<br>    - Surjit Sinha  study tribes from tribe-peasantry continuum (tribe encouraged to work for upper caste as they need services of peasant) after B started cutting trees -> they migrated in seahc of livelihood and started offering peasant services<br>        - Bailey  difference between caste peasant and tribal peasant ;<br>            - Peasant economy is institutional, tribal economy is technological<br>            - Caste peasant has hereditary land and jajmani whereas tribal peasant uses his archaic tech<br>        - Frank fernandes: no jajmani in tribe eg  hira tribe in assam  pots only for hh<br>- Elwin: called them aboriginals; there has been de-tribalization with British onset as railways and other sources of interaction emerged - based on degree of assimilation<br>- GSG  Backward Hindus of hinduized tribe, partially hinduized, hill section<br>    - Tribe became caste by undertaking hindu rituals<br>    - Once they have modern edu, they will develop class character<br>    - Revolution from tribe to caste to class<br>    - Supported by SC Roy  jana and jati are co-existant<br>    - Oppose as some tribes have nth to do with hindu rituals such as NE or Andaman tribes<br>    - NK Bose (used hindu method of acculturization) - <br>        - tribes are hindus in their own way, so dont call them backward; hindus consider only some rivers sacred whereas tribes consider all as scared<br>        - also, tribes preferred over untouchable peasants due to purity pollution<br>    - Five fold classification<br>        - Aboriginals<br>        - Tribals having association with neighbouring society, but maintaining distinctiveness<br>        - Living in village with caste, sects but maintain their identity<br>        - Degraded to status of untouchables<br>        - Assimilated in mainstream and enjoy economic, social status<br>- Hence use features to define instead eg Mandelbaum: 5 features<br>    - Kinship  beyond conventional nuclear, joint  instrument of social bonds<br>    - No hierarchy<br>    - No formal org<br>    - Communitarian  no pvt land holding<br>    - Segmentary<br>    - Little value on surplus accumulation and use of capital and market trading<br>- Dube<br>    - Aboriginals in seclusion, tribals in non-tribal society but distinct, tribal in non-tribal but maintain identity, untouchables, assiminated<br>    - Gonds went to kshatriyaization and became rajgonds<br>    - Who went for agri came in contact with dust and called themselves dhul gonds<br>    - Who still live in forest are tribes<br>- Burman  dif types<br>    - Negative orientation towards hindusim  those tribes who lost their identity due to exposure<br>    - Positive  got a better life<br>    - Assimilated hindu tribes  completely assimilated and may even get high status and land<br>    - Indifferent  who do not believe in Hinduism eg Sentinelese and Orge<br>- Geography<br>    - Northeast  A, AP, M, M (Mizos), N (Nagas), Khasi  Mongolian<br>    - Central  B, J, C, MP, M (Gonds), G, R (Bhils), O ( Santhals ) -proto Australoid<br>    - South  AP, TN, K, K, AN (toda, kadar) - proto Australoid<br>    - North  J&K, HP, UK (Bhotia, gaddi Lohar  Mongolian )<br>    - Pop as % of total varies significantly across states (90% in Naga but 2 digit in Nicobar(<br>- Const safeguards<br>    - Ar 15: special provision for advancement<br>    - 338A: NC for ST<br>    - Fifth and sixth schedule<br>    - 46  state to promote with special care to education and economic interests of SC and ST<br>    - Articles 330 and 332 ---> seats are reserved for SC and ST in Lok Sabha & State Vidhan Sabhas.<br>    - Focus on preserving unique identity of tribes<br>    - Freedom of movement restricted for tribal areas<br>- Caste vs tribe<br>    - Ghurye: tribes are backward hindus<br>        - Said tribe  caste  class<br>    - Continum<br>    - MNS: Tribes enter into caste by Sanskritization ; Dube called it Khatriyaization<br>    - Counter: No pure pollution classification in tribe  so no relation between caste and tribe<br>    - Herbert Risley  endogamy not as rigidly enforced amongst tribes as caste<br>    - Very equal; egalitarian society<br>    - YVS Nath  large number of tribes are entering int caste society via sanskritization  lowest position in caste are reserved for tribes in caste system<br>    - Hoffman and Lister - studied Mundari village with munda tribes  3 agrarian classes within tribes<br>        - Land owner, ryot and agri laborer<br>        - Land owner doesnt till land on his own, lease to ryot (charge 75% as rent)<br>        - Agr labourer moves house to house<br>        - So one group wants another group to work for them<br>        - Hence look frm MOP perspective as class is strong<br>    - Uma Chakrobarty  endogamy to maintain identity unlike caste which is for purity<br>    - Hutton and Mandelbaum  difference but over years have acquired caste traits eg Endogamy and occupational segregation in todas<br>    - RS Sharma  stratification based on age; elder given more importance<br>    - Gender | Colonial policies and tribes                                                                                                                                                                                                     | - **_followed policy of isolation from mainstream as integration -> more revolts_**<br>- **_civilize tribes as easier to manage them_**<br><br>**_Administration related policies  to max revenue_**<br><br>- Phase 1: 1770-1850s<br>    - Rajmahal hills; Cleveland<br>    - Isolate tribal areas - Civil and criminal jurisidiction provided to local elders of the hills instead of British<br>    - But system failed due to corruption<br>    - Response of Paharias of Rajmahal hills<br>- Phase 2 (1860-1919)<br>    - Santhal revolution -> santhal district created<br>    - 1858  Queen Proclamation allowing cultural right of all<br>    - Aimed at economic gain at cost of tribal welfare<br>    - Vidhyarthi says  led to alienation from forest which was not only economy but culture and emotional<br>    - Forest Act OF 1865 and 1878  reserved, protected AD VILLAGE w/o rights to tribals - > made forest a state property<br>- Phase 3 (1919  1947)<br>    - Aimed at isolating tribals<br>    - 2 types  partially excluded (GG takes advice of village administrators) and wholly excluded (GG acted on discretion)<br>    - But compromised as motive was revenue maximization<br>    - High admin as storehouse of minerals and resources<br>- **Christian missionaries engaged to convert them and assimilate them into Christianity Christianisation of tribes  increased gulf between hindus and tribes**<br><br>**_Forest policies_**<br><br>- Mughals  less tax, practice Jhum, traditional rights<br>- Colonial<br>    - 1855: Lord Dalhousie declared "**Teak" a state property** (wood). Restrictions were also put on collections of MFP (**Minor forests produce**)<br>    - 1860s  restrained local policies<br>    - Control over FP through 1878- reserve forest (no access), protected forest (restricted access) and village forest.<br>    - Allowed forest dwellers to enjoy the rights to some extent but **restricted from owning**. --> no pvt forest ; only state property<br>    - Alienation<br>    - Exposed them to money lenders and revenue collectors<br>    - 1871- **criminal tribes act  they were criminals by birth; make systematic record of people who will come to police station every week for reporting**<br>    - **Some protection in 1919 and 1935  excluded and partially excluded**<br>    - **Land transfer act 1917  prevention of land transfer, santhal paragana transfer**<br>- Post indepdence<br>    - 1952 - State ownership<br>    - Use of forest imp for national dev<br>    - Traditional rights no longer rights of tribes  emotional, cultural, economic alientation<br>    - 1988  increase forest cover, but still state ownership<br>    - **2006**  recognized the rights and IPR of tribes; forest comms imp role in protecting forest ecosystems<br>    - Challenges and Impact of British policies<br>        - Vidhyarthi in Nature, man and spirit complex  tribals depend on forest not only for their livelihood but social and cultural needs such as medicine and worship<br>            - It was also reason for women independence and security eg Mahua tribe where women had direct access to forest<br>            - British policies forced them to come to plains and take up diff occupations  led to deculturization and destabilization<br>        - Budhadeb - Made railways to reach tribal areas to extract iron, coal etc  selective access of merchants for economic gains and hence outsierd disrupt social fabric -> convert tribal land into agri land and indiscriminate assimilation leading to detribalization of tribes<br>        - MSA Rao  colonial tribal policy made tribal men destitutes and tribal women prostitutes -> reduced them to low paid work<br>        - **Guha & Gadgil**- colonial rule also led to **ecological imperialism** & forced movt of tribals<br>        - Dube  B drove a wedge between all<br>- into commercial agri from H-G nomadic activities<br>- Tribal uprisings causes<br>    - Deculturation<br>    - Alienation from land<br>    - Exploitation<br>    - Presence of outsider or dikus<br>- PESA act  but only in 60% states<br>- Challenges with Tribals<br>    - Capitalist mode of production (Desai) - Forest rights not protected<br>    - Educationally backward<br>    - Health and nutrition<br>    - Relative deprivation<br>    - Land alienation  Vidyarthi  acquired for mining and development<br>    - Violence<br>    - Integration based on state apparatus  not tribal welfare<br>    - | Integration and autonomy                                                                                                                                                                                                         | - 2 schools of thought<br>    - Integrate and assimilate different as you loose identity in assimilation<br>    - Studies from 2 diff perespectives<br>    - Cultural integration  bye product f caste tribe continuum<br>    - Political  surajit Sinha  need for economic necessaity of peasants to have cheap labor<br>    - Assimilationists  assimilate into mainstream society  Ghurye and LP Vidyarti<br>        - Vidyarti  tribe caste continuum even in ancient sansktrit texts like Ramayana<br>        - Inclusive India<br>        - Promote nationalism<br>        - no social distinctions, no hierarchies<br>        - uniform administration throughout india for integration<br>        - extend benefit of edu health etc for welfare and basic development<br>        - they have been left behind in dev race<br>        - Surjit Sinha  asked for economic integration<br>    - Liberals  provide autonomy to safeguard culture and interests and suit their lifestyle + self governance (like Elwin in his **loss of nerve**)  dont disturb social and cultural life<br>        - Need protection else they will become detribalized landless labour<br>    - Later both converged over integration approach<br>        - Cultural integration (Bailey) and political integration (Surijit)<br>    - Nehru  rejected both **isolation and assimilation -** middle path of integration  assimilate while protecting tribal rights  tribal panchsheel **(CT LOR) - integrate**<br>        - that "one must always remember, however, that we do not mean to interfere with their way of life but want to help them to live it<br>        - Majumdar - Policy of Limited Assimilation<br>        - **Avoid imposing anything on them**. Try to encourage in every way their own **traditional arts and culture**.<br>        - **Tribal rights in land and forest should be respected.**<br>        - Try to train and built up a **team of their own people** to do the work of administration and development. Some technical personnel from outside will, no doubt, be needed, especially in the beginning. But avoid introducing too many outsiders into tribal territory.<br>        - **Do not over-administer** these areas or overwhelm them with a multiplicity of schemes, rather work through, and not in rivalry to their own social and cultural institutions.<br>        - Judge results, not by statistics or the amount of money spent, but by the **quality of human character that is evolved**<br>    - Only implemented in NE Frontier agency (Arunachal)  least militancy  100% literacy  hence successful<br>    - Impact<br>        - Positive  integration in form of states (Jh and Ch)<br>        - Negative  tribal movements and naxalism (like narmada bachao andolan)<br>        - 3 types of groups  co-exist with dominant (bhil), subsumed by dominant (khond), independent of dominant (nagas, mizos)<br>- Xa Xa comm  gram sabha empowerment, no to big dams, tribal coops for mining so that they can use their own produce<br>    - Consider them as sub-citizens because until their problems are addressed, they will not cooperate for democratic process<br>- JANMAN, Van bandhu kalyan joyana, eklavya schools, RGBVs, TRIFED for tribal market<br>- DN Majumdar  best policy is limited assimilation | Industrial class structure                                                                                                                                                                                                       | - Pattern of relationship that exists b/w diff. classes in an Industrial society<br>- Industrialization is the process of machine based mass production with commoditization of labour<br>- But india itself in a qusai industrial society with semi feudal characteristics<br>- Types of structures<br>    - Weber  landed bourgeoise , white collared worker, petty bourgeoise, manual labourer<br>    - Marx  bourgeoise and proletariat<br>    - Bottomore  capitalist, educated class, petty worker and trader, working class (CEPW)<br>    - Functionalists  meet demand in society + employment<br>    - Duncan and Blau: similar income and status people from diff occupations belong to the same class<br>- British onset -> new industries emerge who need labour<br>    - Desai: British dumped their surplus factory produced goods in India and stifled growth of indigenous entrepreneurs on one hand and destroyed domestic handloom industry on the other<br>- Rise in migration, feminization of agri -> displacement; footloose labour + daily wake workers + poor regulations + exploitation + long work hours + child labour<br>- Capital class emerged -> owned capital and equipment -> further grew during import substitution<br>- A new class -> middle mgt emerged<br>- Impact on caste<br>    - Goulds - Rickshawalla  high caste could now do low class work as anonymity<br>    - Class caste similar hierarchy (caste ch)<br>    - AB: high class not always high caste; caste weakening not dying<br>    - Caste class nexus<br>    - Reservations + democracy -> reducing caste barriers for class mobility<br>    - Industry is more or less caste blind<br>    - Also led to caste clustering as people from same village used to migrate and then work<br>- Post industrial<br>    - **Daniel Bell:** shift from industry to service, with focus on science and data -> info age (similar trends seen in America with services employing majority workforce)<br>    - **Impact :** solves problems of industrialization incl.<br>        - Alienation reduced as creativity increases<br>        - New better offices to work<br>        - Customer customization<br>        - Migration to tech hubs<br>        - People interaction and not just machines<br>        - Unity of work<br>        - Better ownership of work<br>        - Growing professionals in white collared jobs<br>    - Criticism: too rosy a pictures<br>        - Urban sprawl<br>        - Marxists wont agree<br>        - Agri will reduce<br>        - Feminization of agri<br>        - New types of issues such as anxiety and stress<br>        - Sexual harrassament<br>        - Pay gap<br>        - A lot of jobs have similar nature<br>        - Not all offices are nice<br>        - Fragmentation of tasks<br>        - Less freedom  doing what others have to do<br>        - Bardhan and rudra- liberalization inflated assets of capitalist class at the cst of working class<br>    - In a post-independence era:<br>        - New reforms introduced<br>        - Holmstorm, Dev Nathan  Working Class in India is of 4 types <br>            - 1. diff<br>    - fathers brother is distinguished from fathers sister<br>    - Fathers brothers are also distinguished in terms of age (tau chachu)<br>    - Highly patrilineal kins (descent criteria south **Attai** is used for<br>    - both Phuphi and Mami. **Mama** is used for both Phupha and Mama.<br>    - Uniliear<br>    - Rule of marriage is highly exhaustive  7 gens <br>    - **negative with or near the husband's parents.)<br>    - Veena Das- In north Indian kinship  father son relationship precedes over husband wife -> patriarchy and consanguineal stronger<br>    - Hostility of group ~ mothers brother group -> mamu = fufu= Mamu<br>    - Specific matri  specific patri<br>    - Love for younger and respect for elders; father = brother; mom = elder sister; younger brother  son<br>    - Symmetrical relations with bride and groom kins; terms used to address<br>    - Uniliear<br>    - Marriage not between villages but limited kinship of mother and father side<br>    - **positive rules of marriage  who you can marry**<br>    - Cross cousins marriage allowable exogamy not exhaustive like north India.<br>    - Husband wife relationship is not subdued to father son relationship<br>    - Low suscpicion<br>    - **Preferential marriage (with matrilineal or patri kins  no bride giver supremacy) eg- marry elder suster daughter, father sister daughter**<br>    - - Gifts equal on both sides unlike unidirectional in north india towards bride taker<br>- Similarity<br>    - Caste and kinship intertwined  purity pollution influences<br>    - Unilineal descent  not       - 2 village exogamy<br>    - Levirate common  brother marrys dead brothers wife<br>- East India<br>    - Munda of Odisha + NE (Manipuri of Manipur, Nagas, Kukis and Khasi.)<br>    - High | Household                                                                                                                                                                                                                        | - - IP Desai -> cyclical pattern of patrilocal, neolocal, patrilocal -> JH may disappear, JF stay<br>    - Pauline Kolenda<br>        - After modernity, joint households and joint families still exist.<br>        - # of Nuclear is more than JF.<br>        - Avg size of household increasing (death rate less, life longetivity).<br>        - Household have lifecycle (fission - fusion - fission)<br>        - Rural household size > urban size<br>        - Regional difference (North India JF > South)<br>- Feminist: Nuclear or Joint -> not affecting women DOL -> increasing load on women<br>- Land is basis of jointness  hence not in landless farmers<br>- Family is the basic and universal social structure of human society. It fulfils needs and perform<br>- functions which are indispensable for the continuity, integration and change in the social system.<br>- Iravati Karve (1953) writes, A joint family is a group of people who generally live under one roof,<br>- who eat food cooked in one kitchen, who hold property in common, participate in common family<br>- worship and are related to one another as some particular type of kindred.<br>- Karves definition of joint family refers to an ideal situation of family life in terms of its corporate<br>- character. In any case, in structural terms, joint family implies living together of members of two<br>- or more elementary families both lineally and laterally.<br>- Traditional peasant societies everywhere in the world had a predominance of extended joint<br>- families. The forms and functions of family have undergone adaptive changes with the changes in the<br>- technological and economic superstructure of society.<br>- One way to characterise this change is to associate conjugal or nuclear forms of families with<br>- relatively modernised or industrial society and extended or joint types of families with traditional<br>- agrarian and pre-industrial societies.<br>- The transition from extended family-based society to nuclear family-based society is thus, in essence,<br>- an example of structural change, since this involves systematic changes in role-structures through<br>- process of differentiation.<br>- Extended families which are the dominant pattern in India have existed side by side with nuclear<br>- families. Changes are now taking place in both of these traditional family forms; this bears significant<br>- relationship with the direction of social change and modernization in India.<br>- The studies concerning the distribution of family types (structurally) in India shows results which<br>- considerably fluctuate on the basis of criteria employed for the classification of jointness. Defining<br>- jointness with reference to residence, property and mutual obligations among the kin, I. P. Desai<br>- offers four categories of family types:<br>- 1a: husband and wife only;<br>- 1b: uni-member households;<br>- 2a: husband, wife and married sons without children and other unmarried children;<br>- 2b: the above group with other relatives who do not add to generation depth;<br>- 3: three generation groups of lineal descendants;<br>- 4: four or more than four generations of lineal descendants; under the group of nuclear family I. P.<br>- Desai includes the family types 1a to 2b, and his studies shows that such families in Mahuva (a town<br>- For Rushikesh Palimkar(rrpb703@gmail.com)<br>- 18 www.visionias.in Vision IAS<br>- in Gujarat) constitute 61% (260 out of 423) of the total; types 3 and 4 which he defines as joint<br>- families make the rest of the 39%.<br>- Desai makes a distinction between the nuclearity or jointness of family types as a structural<br>- phenomenon (lineal-collateral depth) and the degree of sentiment of jointness in each family-type<br>- derived from the relationships as obtaining among those living in one household and between the<br>- relatives who are living in another household (quality of interaction pattern).<br>- Evaluating the structurally nuclear and joint families on the sentimental criteria of jointness he finds<br>- that 70 families in Mahuva which are classified as nuclear on structural criteria comprise the high<br>- category on the scale of the sentiment of jointness; 51 such nuclear families are in the higher<br>- category and 6 families in the highest category on the scale of sentiment of jointness.<br>- Desai argues that excluding the 5% families where sentiment of jointness is zero, 95% of the<br>- total sample families have sentiment of jointness ranging from low to highest degree in the<br>- village of Mahuva.<br>- Family jointness still continues to be a major sociological phenomenon in the Indian social structure,<br>- being unaffected by the differences of religion, caste, urbanization and occupation. In Mahuva, not<br>- only Hindus but the Jains and the Muslims have joint families.<br>- The findings of K. M. Kapadia support the conclusions of I. P. Desai. In a comparative study of family<br>- patterns in the Navasari town and fifteen villages from the same region with varying degrees of<br>- urban impact, Kapadia found that joint family pattern was not only predominant but contrary to the<br>- popular image was stronger in the towns in comparison to the villages.<br>- The nuclear family of the West is a product of Industrial Revolution which altered the whole pattern<br>- of economic and kinship relations. In the absence of such existential conditions nuclear families could<br>- not have been self-supporting or self-perpetuating in an agrarian caste-ridden society like that of<br>- India. In this context, I. P. Desai and other sociologists assert that there is no linear evolutionary<br>- differentiation from joint to nuclear family organisation.<br>- Dube contends that, The traditional typology of simple, compound and extended family does not<br>- accurately fit the forms of family organisation met with in India. At one point of time, the size and<br>- actual composition of a family often denotes only a particular stage in its developmental cycle. Simple<br>- families grow into extended families and then break up into simple families again.<br>- A wider picture of changes in the family structure in India can be gained only by comparative regional<br>- studies (as done by Pauline M. Kolenda who has classified family types into twelve categories for<br>- comparative evaluation). | Programs for rural dev                                                                                                                                                                                                           | - Rural dev - Improving living standards and life chances of low-income rural population.<br>- Rural Development is much broader than Agricultures Development.<br>- But since agriculture is the main source of employment, therefore, main focus is always on agriculture.<br>- Rural Development aims to provide below mentioned aspects:<br>- Need for rural dev<br>    - 80% pop lived in rural areas<br>    - 60% income from agri<br>    - Need to ensure food security<br>    - Socio-Economic equality TO control migration<br>- Schemes<br>    - CDP  infra dev with community<br>    - Extension scheme<br>    - Coop  voluntary org to achieve collective and individual interests, through synergy and ownership sharing eg Amul<br>    - PRI<br>    - GR<br>    - 20 pt program for poverty alleviation, IRRIGATION, min wages, PHC facilities etc.<br>    - IRD<br>    - NREG<br>- Critique<br>    - Arm chair approach by politicians and bureucrats  no on ground reality<br>    - AR Desai  myth of welfare  no real impact and focused on political power consolidation<br>    - Rural industry didnt receive due status  only agri<br>    - Y Sigh  created rural elite with antagonistic relations<br>    - Rajni Kothari  benefit only large farmers as smaller still dont have land, knowledge about DBT, skill dev<br>    - PRI 3F failed<br><br>Current programs<br><br>- Voluntarist  CSR funding<br>- participative approach<br>- Targeted approach  PM Kisan<br>- Capitalists approach - SHG<br>- Resource based approach  MPLADS, gram sadak yojana, PMAY<br>- Clinical approach  disaster affected  so miigation fund<br>- Socialist approach  sevashrams, shanti niketan<br>- Modernists  empirical and technical cap building | Community dev program                                                                                                                                                                                                            | - 1952 -> multi-project program<br>- Community dev is the process of **social** action where people organize themselves for planning, design, implementation and defining problems<br>- Based on Gandhian concept of Sevagram  Self sufficiency<br>- Inspired from some pre-independence dev initiatives<br>- Idea -> villages consist of common commodity with community Solidarity<br>- AIM  development of all through collective participation<br>- Tagore  Shantiniketan also<br>- Plan -> every family sends atleast one person to give free labor -> develop a sense of belonging<br>    - Aim was to increase production, develop comm, healthcare, cottage industry, community assets, village edu etc<br>- Started throughout India initially but impossible<br>- As limited resources, 3 phases of CDP <br>    - National Extension phase  Areas selected with little govt expenditure<br>    - Intensive Community Development phase  Blocks selected high govt expenditure with dimensions included such as health, edu, rural industries, sanitation etc; these blocks will become self sufficient<br>    - Post development stage  MEL<br>- By 1957  4 Major categories <br>    - Constructional Programs (schools, roads etc.)<br>    - Irrigation (wells , tubewells, pumps etc.)<br>    - Agriculture (waste land dev, soil, manure etc.)<br>    - Institutional Programs (youth, women, dispensaries, smokeless chulhas etc.)<br>- **N Patnaik** in his study of Odisha- CDP freed the poor from clutches of self-conflict & non-sympathy<br>- But it Failed.<br>- Criticism<br>    - Created Community dependence on govt<br>    - Interests of landed class not same with service and other classes<br>    - Bureaucracy lacked social service ethos -> werent interested<br>    - Development top-down. Slow and **extensive bureaucratization**<br>    - Land owners more benefitted.<br>    - Great emphasis on Economic aspect. Little on social and technical.<br>    - Dominant castes hijacked top positions and diverted subsidy benefits.<br>    - Lack of appropriate training<br>- Taylor -> didnt imbibe true spirit in program as dependent more on govt schemes<br>- Desai -> flawed assumption that comm has common interest; ignored the irreconcilable differences on ground<br>- Dube  top down approach faulty<br>- Oscar Lewis  lack of social service mentality in officials; clear adhocism replaced plan | Cooperatives                                                                                                                                                                                                                     | - Voluntary group of people who use common resources to achieve collective and individual benefit<br>- Intermediaries are cut or reduced<br>- Existed before Independence as well. Coop. started in Germany, 1890s  couldnt pay tax revenue to new classes and hence British encouraged<br>- Passed coop act 1904 and coop act 1912<br>- Eg  AMUL, IFFCO, NAFED, NCCF, can be rural credit socs also<br>- First coop in India in 1905<br>- 2002  Nat policy on coop emowering them to undertake business transactions<br>    - granted autonomy in working with govts role limited to conduct of timely elections, audit<br>    - State is committed to the cause of devt of SC/ST, women through co-ops<br>    - State should phase out its shareholding in co-ops to retain its autonomous character<br>    - Co-ops must be allowed to est holdin Cos, enter into strategic pships & venture into sunrise sectors<br>    - Reduce regional imbalances in est of co-op<br>    - New m-state co-op societies act passed replacing the 1942 one<br>- 2012  Const Am<br>- 2021  Min of coop<br>- Importance<br>    - Mobilization of resources for poverty alleviation and productivity<br>    - Credit and non-credit coops<br>    - Non agri coops to develop rural industry<br>    - Employment and organization<br>    - Provision of cheaper tools to rural comm<br>    - Bargaining power to farmers<br>    - Industry market agri linkages<br>- Const  Ar 43, Ar 243 (B), Ar 19 (1) (c)<br>- Success story  AMUL, IFFCO, Kerala fishermen coop<br>- Jan Breman  studied kerala coops and observed improvement amongst farmers<br>- PR Dubhasi  cover every field and are social movements not mere orgs<br>- AR Desai : can overcome the debacle of agrarian social order  in favour of the model<br>- Limitations<br>    - Daniel Thorner - State coop farms had poor quality land given to landless and lower castes. Extremely high cost of running them proved fatal for their success<br>        - Case of public money given to private investment ; v small % of credit to small and marginal farmer<br>        - Coop hijacked by rich sections and became their serving interest<br>    - BS Baviskar  power conflict marred success and coop politics<br>    - Vibha Arora  depeasantization due to transnational companies  producitivty increased but process slow<br>    - Satyadev  best seeds were used by landlords in Haryana<br>    - Over-burecratization<br>    - Lack of professional mgt<br>    - Lack of funding<br>- Contemporary<br>    - 100% reach in villages<br>    - 15% credit; 59% fertilizer distribution | Poverty Alleviation Schemes                                                                                                                                                                                                      | - Many schemes, Important ones being<br>    - 20 points programme  Controlling poverty, inflation, lending, crime control, irrigation, rural employment, SC/ST specific programs, women/children specific etc.<br>    - Integrated Rural Dev Program (IRDP)  1982. Loans to promote Self-employment by SC ST/ farmers<br>        - . Targeted approach based on  (i) Number of poor households. (ii) Resources available. (iii) Time-span for results. Limitation  (i) Leakages. (ii) Finding guarantor. (iii) Misallocation of loans. (iv) Little knowledge of schemes.<br>    - TRYSEM (Training Rural Youth for Self Employement)  Age 18-35. Priority to SC/ST. But inadequate stipend and low level of skills given.<br>    - Food for Work Prog<br>    - MNREGA  (with social impacts) o<br>        - Right based - Work given in time bound guarantee (15 days) (liability on State).<br>        - Women Empowerment  1/3 persons have to be women. <br>        - Work Site facilities  Crche, water, shade etc. ;<br>        - Work within 5kms<br>        - Decentralised Planning  50% of the work to be allotted to Gram Panchayats.<br>        - labour Intensive Work  60:40 ratio of wage and material. Machinery prohibited.<br>        - Public Accountability  Social Audits.<br>        - Transparency  All records available to anyone on payment of a fee.<br>        - Low quality Asset created<br>        - Policies generally arm chair. Does not resonate with ground reality.<br>    - Evaluation of MNREGA<br>        - Populist approach. Less emphasis on 3Es. (Efficiency, Economy, Effectiveness)<br>        - o No focus on rural-industrialisation.<br>        - o No coordination among various programmes.<br>        - o Improper delivery of funds. /ghost Beneficiaries<br>        - o No effective awareness building measures.<br>        - o Increased dependence of masses on state<br>        - o Women given work (48% of total)<br>        - **Jean Dreze** - poverty reduced by 30% due to MGNREGA<br>        - **Poor reain poor**  vote bank politics<br>        - **Dependency**<br>        - Rajni Kothari<br>    - direct benefit transfer<br>    - skilling and dev -> Kaushal vikas yojana<br>    - Drought prone area dev program<br>    - Mudra<br>    - Deen dayal antodya yojana<br>    - IG National old age pension scheme<br>    - Dev of rural areas like gram sadak, gramodaya yojana<br>- focus as 55% pop was poor ; 15% multi-dimensional still exists<br>- india 5th largest in nominal terms but 142 in PPP GDP<br>- MDP -> Amartya Sen  poverty is lack of what one needs to live in society, not only to survive<br>- Amartya sen  people have multiple identities due to muddls hierarchies
